revision.comment: removing a protection template from a non-protected page ([[User:DumbBOT/Protection|info]])
revision.text:
{{about|the media franchise|the title character|Doraemon (character)|other uses}} {{short description|Japanese manga series}} {{Infobox animanga/Header | image = Doraemon volume 1 cover.jpg | caption = Volume 1 of ''Doraemon'' | ja_kanji = ドラえもん | ja_romaji = | genre = [[Comedy]],{{cite web |title=SHOGAKUKAN-SHUEISHA PRODUCTIONS GRANTS MERCHANDISE RIGHTS FOR BELOVED DORAEMON FRANCHISE TO VIZ MEDIA FOR AMERICAS REGION |url=https://www.viz.com/news/newsroom/1006120 |publisher=[[Viz Media]] |accessdate=January 22, 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190122195515/https://www.viz.com/news/newsroom/1006120 |archive-date=January 22, 2019 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }} [[science fiction]]{{cite web |author1=Bang Ong |title=10 Asian heroes we worshipped while growing up |url=https://www.stuff.tv/my/features/10-asian-heroes-we-worshipped-while-growing/doraemon |publisher=[[Stuff (magazine)|Stuff]] |accessdate=January 22, 2019 |date=August 28, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190122195613/https://www.stuff.tv/my/features/10-asian-heroes-we-worshipped-while-growing/doraemon |archive-date=January 22, 2019 |url-status=live |df=mdy-all }} }} {{Infobox animanga/Print | type = manga | author = [[Fujiko Fujio]] | publisher = [[Shogakukan]] | publisher_en = {{English manga publisher|NA=[[Fujiko Fujio|Fujiko Pro]]|SG=[[Shogakukan Asia]]|JP=Shogakukan (bilingual)|CN=21st Century Publishing House (bilingual English-Chinese)}} | demographic = [[Children's anime and manga|''Kodomo'']] | imprint = Tentōmushi Comics | magazine = {{Noitalic|Various Shogakukan children's magazines}} | first = August 8, 1969
(adverts)
January 1970
(first full story published) | last = June 23, 1996 | volumes = 45 | volume_list = List of Doraemon chapters }} {{Infobox animanga/Other | title = Anime television series | content = *''[[Doraemon (1973 TV series)|Doraemon]]'' (1973 anime) *''[[Doraemon (1979 TV series)|Doraemon]]'' (1979 anime) *''[[Doraemon (2005 TV series)|Doraemon]]'' (2005 anime) }} {{Infobox animanga/Other | title = Related works | content = *''[[The Doraemons]]'' *''[[Dorabase]]'' }} {{Infobox animanga/Footer}} '''''Doraemon''''' ({{lang-ja|ドラえもん}} {{IPA-ja|do̞ɾa̠e̞mõ̞ɴ}}) is a Japanese [[manga]] series written and illustrated by [[Fujiko Fujio]], the pen name of the duo Hiroshi Fujimoto and Motoo Abiko. The series has also been adapted into a successful [[anime]] series and [[media franchise]]. The story revolves around an earless robotic cat named [[Doraemon (character)|Doraemon]], who [[time travel|travels back in time]] from the 22nd century to aid a boy named {{nihongo|[[Nobita Nobi]]|野比のび太|Nobi Nobita}}. The first full story in the Doraemon manga series was published in January 1970. A pre-advertisement for the manga was published in six different magazines in December 1969. A total of 1,465 stories were created in the original series, which are published by [[Shogakukan]]. It is [[List of best-selling manga|one of the best-selling manga in the world]], and has sold over 100 million copies {{as of|2015|lc=y}}. The volumes are collected in the Takaoka Central Library in [[Toyama Prefecture|Toyama]], Japan, where Fujiko Fujio was born. [[Turner Broadcasting System]] bought the rights to the Doraemon anime series in the mid-1980s for an English-language release in the United States,{{cite web |url=http://www.jref.com/japan/travel/prefectures/kanagawa/doraemon_museum.shtml |title=Fujiko F. Fujio Museum |publisher=Japan Reference |accessdate=September 11, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120919194200/http://jref.com/japan/travel/prefectures/kanagawa/doraemon_museum.shtml |archive-date=2012-09-19 |url-status=live }} but cancelled it without explanation before broadcasting any episodes. In July 2013, [[Voyager Books|Voyager Japan]] announced the manga would be released digitally in English via the [[Amazon Kindle]] [[e-book]] service. Awards for Doraemon include the [[Japan Cartoonists Association Award]] for excellence in 1973, the first [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for [[Children's anime and manga|children's manga]] in 1982, and the first [[Osamu Tezuka Culture Award]] in 1997. In March 2008, [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Japan's Foreign Ministry]] appointed Doraemon as the nation's first "anime ambassador." A Ministry spokesperson explained the novel decision as an attempt to help people in other countries understand Japanese anime better and to deepen their interest in [[Japanese culture]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/431177|title=Doraemon named 'anime ambassador'|last=AFP|date=March 15, 2008|website=[[Japan Today]]|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080318231731/http://www.japantoday.com/jp/news/431177|archive-date=March 18, 2008|url-status=dead|df=mdy-all}} The Foreign Ministry action confirms that Doraemon has come to be considered a Japanese cultural icon. [[Doraemon in India|In India]], its [[Hindi]], [[Telugu language|Telugu]] and [[Tamil language|Tamil]] translation has been telecasted, where the anime version is the highest-rated kids' show; winning the ''Best Show For Kids'' award twice at the [[Nickelodeon Kids' Choice Awards India]] in 2013 and 2015. In 2002 ''[[Time Asia]]'' magazine acclaimed the character as an "Asian Hero" in a special feature survey. An edited English dub distributed by [[TV Asahi]] aired on [[Disney XD]] in the United States started on July 7, 2014. On August 17, 2015, another English dubbed version distributed by Luk Internacional began broadcasting on [[Boomerang (UK & Ireland)|Boomerang UK]]. The [[List of Doraemon films|film series]] is the largest by number of admissions in Japan. ==Plot== {{See also|List of Doraemon characters}} Doraemon, a cat robot from the 22nd century, is sent to help [[Nobita Nobi]], a young boy, who scores poor grades and is frequently bullied by his two classmates, Gian and Suneo so that his descendants can improve their lives (Doraemon is sent by Sewashi Nobi, Nobita's future grandson). [[Doraemon (character)|Doraemon]] has a four-dimensional pouch in which he stores unexpected gadgets that improve his life. He has many gadgets, which he gets from The Future Departmental Store, such as Bamboo-Copter, a small piece of headgear that can allow its users to fly; Anywhere Door, a pink-colored door that allows people to travel according to the thoughts of the person who turns the knob; Time Kerchief, a handkerchief that can turn an object new or old or a person young or old; Translator Tool, a cuboid jelly that can allow people to converse in any language across the universe; Designer Camera, a camera that produces dresses; and many more. Nobita's closest friend and love interest is [[Shizuka Minamoto]], who eventually becomes his wife in the future and has a child with him named Nobisuke Nobi (the same name as Nobita's father). Nobita is often bullied by [[Takeshi Goda]] (nicknamed "Gian"), and Suneo Honekawa (Gian's sidekick), but they are shown to be friends in some of the episodes. In most episodes, a typical story consists of Nobita taking a gadget from Doraemon for his needs eventually causing more trouble than he was trying to solve. As for the movies, Doraemon, Nobita, Shizuka, Suneo, and Gian are often shown ready for an adventure to protect people. They are adventurous, humorous, and emotional. ===Manga=== {{See also|List of Doraemon chapters|List of Doraemon Plus chapters}} [[File:Doraemon first appearance.jpg|thumb|250px|The first appearance of Doraemon, who came via the [[time travel|time machine]].]] In December 1969 the ''Doraemon'' manga appeared in six different children's monthly magazines published by [[Shogakukan]]. The magazines were aimed at children from nursery school to fourth grade. In 1977 ''[[CoroCoro Comic]]'' was launched as the flagship magazine of ''Doraemon.''{{cite book|title=The Rough Guide to Manga|last=S. Yada|first=Jason|publisher=[[Rough Guides]]|isbn=978-1-85828-561-0|pages=114–115|date=October 2009}} Since the debut of ''Doraemon'' in 1969, the stories have been selectively collected into forty-five [[tankōbon]] volumes, which were published under Shogakukan's ''Tentōmushi Comics'' imprint, from 1974 to 1996. Shogakukan published a ''master works'' collection consisting of twenty volumes between July 24, 2009 and September 25, 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.shogakukan.co.jp/comics/detail/_isbn_9784091434036|title=藤子・Ｆ・不二雄大全集　ドラえもん　１|accessdate=January 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115194711/http://www.shogakukan.co.jp/comics/detail/_isbn_9784091434036|archive-date=2013-01-15|url-status=live}}{{cite web|url=http://www.shogakukan.co.jp/comics/detail/_isbn_9784091435019|title=藤子・Ｆ・不二雄大全集　ドラえもん　２０|accessdate=January 5, 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150113233150/http://www.shogakukan.co.jp/comics/detail/_isbn_9784091435019|archive-date=2015-01-13|url-status=live}} In addition, Doraemon has appeared in a variety of manga series by Shōgakukan. In 2005 Shōgakukan published a series of five more manga volumes under the title ''Doraemon+'' (''[[Doraemon Plus]]''), which were not found in the forty-five original volumes. On December 1, 2014, a sixth volume of ''Doraemon Plus'' was published. This was the first volume in eight years.{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-11-15/1st-doraemon-manga-volume-in-8-years-ships-in-december/.81061 |title=1st Doraemon Manga Volume in 8 Years Ships in December |work=[[Anime News Network]] |date=November 15, 2014 |accessdate=December 24, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20141220033505/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-11-15/1st-doraemon-manga-volume-in-8-years-ships-in-december/.81061 |archive-date=2014-12-20 |url-status=live }} There have been two series of bilingual, Japanese and English, volumes of the manga by SHOGAKUKAN ENGLISH COMICS under the title ''Doraemon: Gadget Cat from the Future'', and two audio versions.{{Cite web |url=https://www.shogakukan.co.jp/books/series/B30012 |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-10-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161019025626/https://www.shogakukan.co.jp/books/series/B30012 |archive-date=2016-10-19 |url-status=live }}{{cite book|title=Manga:The Complete Guide|last=Thompson|first=Jason|publisher=Del Rey Books|isbn=978-0-345-48590-8|pages=85–86|authorlink=Jason Thompson (writer)|year=2007}} The first series has ten volumes and the second six. In addition, 21st Century Publishing House (二十一世纪出版社集团) released bilingual English-Chinese versions in Mainland China.{{cite web|url=http://www.21cccc.com/mainpages/bookInfo.aspx?ID=504|title=哆啦A梦英汉双语精华本1|publisher=21st Century Publishing House|accessdate=2018-12-01|archive-url=https://archive.today/20181201080203/http://www.21cccc.com/mainpages/bookInfo.aspx?ID=504|archive-date=2018-12-01|url-status=dead}}( [[archive.is]]) In July 2013, Fujiko Fujio Productions announced that they would be collaborating with ebook publisher [[Voyager Books|Voyager Japan]] and localization company [[AltJapan Co., Ltd.]] to release an English language version of the manga in full-color digitally via the [[Amazon Kindle]] platform in North America.{{cite news|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-07-28/doraemon-manga-digital-release-coming-to-north-america|title=Classic Kids' Manga Doraemon Coming to N. America Digitally|work=Anime News Network|date=July 28, 2013|accessdate=December 4, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203220030/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2013-07-28/doraemon-manga-digital-release-coming-to-north-america|archive-date=2013-12-03|url-status=live}} Shogakukan released the first volume in November 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B00GTG4776/ |title=DORAEMON Vol.1 [Kindle Edition]|accessdate= December 4, 2013}} This English version incorporates a variety of changes to character names; Nobita is "Noby", Shizuka is "Sue", Suneo is "Sneech", and Gian is "Big G", while dorayaki is "Yummy Bun/Fudgy Pudgy Pie."{{cite news|url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/social_affairs/AJ201311230013 |title=English version of 'Doraemon' to enter North American market |work=[[Asahi Shimbun]] |date=November 23, 2013 |accessdate=December 4, 2013 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203082158/https://ajw.asahi.com/article/behind_news/social_affairs/AJ201311230013 |archivedate=December 3, 2013 }} A total of 200 volumes have been released. The manga has been published in English in print by [[Shogakukan Asia]], using the same translation as the manga available on Amazon Kindle. Unlike the Amazon Kindle releases these volumes are in black and white instead of color. They have released four volumes.{{Cite web |url=http://shogakukan.asia/doraemon-4/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=2016-10-16 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161012054715/http://shogakukan.asia/doraemon-4/ |archive-date=2016-10-12 |url-status=live }} [[Shogakukan]] started digital distribution of all forty-five original volumes throughout Japan from July 16, 2015.{{Cite web|url=http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2015/07/16/doraemon-begins-digital-distribution-in-japan|title="Doraemon" Begins Digital Distribution in Japan|last=Chapman|first=Paul|date=16 July 2015|website=[[Crunchyroll]]|access-date=17 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160424184133/http://www.crunchyroll.com/anime-news/2015/07/16/doraemon-begins-digital-distribution-in-japan|archive-date=2016-04-24|url-status=live}} ===Anime=== After a brief first attempt at an [[Doraemon (1973 anime)|animated series]] in 1973 by [[Nippon Television]], ''Doraemon'' remained fairly exclusive in manga form until 1979 when a newly formed animation studio, [[Shin-Ei Animation]] (now owned by [[TV Asahi]]) produced an animated [[Doraemon (1979 anime)|second attempt]] of ''Doraemon.''{{cite book|last1=Schilling|first1=Mark|title=The Encyclopedia of Japanese Pop Culture|date=1997|publisher=Weatherhill|location=New York|page=39}} This series became incredibly popular, and ended with 1,787 episodes on March 25, 2005. In [[Asia]], this version is sometimes referred to as the Ōyama Edition, after the [[Nobuyo Ōyama|voice actress]] who voiced Doraemon in this series.{{Cite web|url=http://www.inmediahk.net/node/1002380|title=舊酒新瓶？濃厚也 (Old Wine In New Bottle? It's Rich)|date=25 February 2009|website=inmediahk.net|access-date=9 June 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160816123832/http://www.inmediahk.net/node/1002380|archive-date=2016-08-16|url-status=live}} Celebrating the anniversary of the franchise, a third ''Doraemon'' [[Doraemon (2005 anime)|animated series]] began airing on TV Asahi on April 15, 2005 with new [[seiyū|voice actors]] and staff, and updated character designs.{{Cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2005/04/10/tv/the-all-new-doraemon-premieres-on-tv-asahi-with-an-hour-long-special-and-more/|title=The all-new "Doraemon" premieres on TV Asahi with an hour-long special and more|date=10 April 2005|website=[[The Japan Times]]|access-date=16 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428132452/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2005/04/10/tv/the-all-new-doraemon-premieres-on-tv-asahi-with-an-hour-long-special-and-more/|archive-date=2016-04-28|url-status=live}} This version is sometimes referred to in Asia as the Mizuta Edition, as [[Wasabi Mizuta]] is the voice actress for Doraemon in this series. On May 12, 2014, TV Asahi Corporation announced an agreement with [[The Walt Disney Company]] to [[Doraemon: Gadget Cat from the Future|bring the 2005 series to the Disney XD television channel in the United States]] beginning in the summer of that year.{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2014/05/09/japanese-anime-star-doraemon-finally-makes-u-s-debut/|title=Japanese Anime Star Doraemon Finally Makes U.S. Debut|last=Hongo|first=Jun|date=9 May 2014|website=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|access-date=16 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160420175959/http://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2014/05/09/japanese-anime-star-doraemon-finally-makes-u-s-debut/|archive-date=2016-04-20|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/06/25/national/doraemon-hitting-u-s-airwaves-summer/|title=Doraemon hitting U.S. airwaves this summer|last=Kagawa|first=Marcie|date=25 June 2014|website=[[The Japan Times]]|access-date=16 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160428080028/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/06/25/national/doraemon-hitting-u-s-airwaves-summer/|archive-date=2016-04-28|url-status=live}}{{Cite web|url=http://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Consumers/Doraemon-plans-to-make-US-debut-this-summer|title=Doraemon plans to make US debut this summer|date=9 May 2014|website=[[Nikkey Shimbun]]|access-date=16 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140523130822/http://asia.nikkei.com/Business/Consumers/Doraemon-plans-to-make-US-debut-this-summer|archive-date=2014-05-23|url-status=live}} Besides using the name changes that were used in AltJapan's English adaptation of the original manga, other changes and edits have also been made to make the show more relatable to an American audience, such as Japanese text being replaced with English text on certain objects like signs and graded papers, items such as [[Japanese yen|yen notes]] being replaced by [[United States dollar|US dollar bills]], and the setting being changed from Japan to the United States.{{Cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-05-11/doraemon-anime-visual-and-script-changes-for-u.s-tv-detailed|title=Doraemon Anime's Visual & Script Changes for U.S. TV Detailed|date=11 May 2014|website=[[Anime News Network]]|access-date=16 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140513220034/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2014-05-11/doraemon-anime-visual-and-script-changes-for-u.s-tv-detailed|archive-date=2014-05-13|url-status=live}} Confirmed cast member of the new American adaptation include veteran anime voice actress [[Mona Marshall]] of ''[[South Park]]'' fame in the title role of Doraemon and [[Johnny Yong Bosch]] of ''[[Mighty Morphin Power Rangers|Power Rangers]]'' and ''[[Bleach (anime)|Bleach]]'' fame as Noby. The English dub is produced by [[Bang Zoom! Entertainment]].{{cite web |url=http://licensing14.mapyourshow.com/5_0/exhibitor_details.cfm?exhid=12699&CFID=36365735&CFTOKEN=aec74be628e68047-E8748238-C778-32EC-687CB555182920BF |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-05-22 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140512215952/http://licensing14.mapyourshow.com/5_0/exhibitor_details.cfm?exhid=12699&CFID=36365735&CFTOKEN=aec74be628e68047-E8748238-C778-32EC-687CB555182920BF |archivedate=2014-05-12 }} Initial response to the edited dub was positive.{{Cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/07/09/national/doraemon-charms-u-s-viewers-in-first-remake-for-a-foreign-market/|title=Doraemon charms U.S. viewers in first remake for a foreign market|last=Kagawa|first=Marcie|date=9 July 2014|website=[[The Japan Times]]|access-date=16 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160427010316/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2014/07/09/national/doraemon-charms-u-s-viewers-in-first-remake-for-a-foreign-market|archive-date=2016-04-27|url-status=live}} The Disney adaptation began broadcast in Japan on [[Disney Channel Japan|Disney Channel]] from February 1, 2016. The broadcast offered the choice of the English voice track or a newly recorded Japanese track by the US cast.{{cite news |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-01-30/disney-xd-doraemon-adaptation-to-run-in-japan-with-bilingual-tracks/.98067 |title=Disney XD's Doraemon Adaptation to Run in Japan With Bilingual Tracks |work=[[Anime News Network]] |date=January 30, 2015 |accessdate=January 30, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160131082928/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-01-30/disney-xd-doraemon-adaptation-to-run-in-japan-with-bilingual-tracks/.98067 |archive-date=2016-01-31 |url-status=live }} In [[EMEA]] regions, the series is licensed by LUK International.{{cite web |url=http://www.lukinternacional.com/en/catalogue/doraemon.html |title=Catalogue / DORAEMON |accessdate=November 29, 2016 |publisher=LUK International |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161129144402/http://www.lukinternacional.com/en/catalogue/doraemon.html |archive-date=2016-11-29 |url-status=live }} The series began broadcast in the United Kingdom on August 17, 2015 on [[Boomerang (UK & Ireland)|Boomerang]].https://web.archive.org/web/20160308192946/http://www.doraemon-world.com/en/NEWS/attention%2Ball%2Buk%2Bfans%2C%2Bdoraemon%2Bis%2Bcoming%2Bto%2Bboomerang ====Feature films==== {{Further|List of Doraemon films}} In 1980, [[Toho]] released the first of a series of annual feature-length [[animated film]]s based on the lengthy special volumes published annually. Unlike the anime and manga (some based on the stories in select volumes), they are more action-adventure oriented and have more of a [[Shōnen manga|shōnen]] demographic, taking the familiar characters of ''Doraemon'' and placing them in a variety of exotic and perilous settings. Nobita and his friends have visited the age of the [[dinosaur]]s, the far reaches of the [[galaxy]], the depths of the ocean, and a world of [[magic (paranormal)|magic]]. Some of the films are based on [[legend]]s such as [[Atlantis]], and on literary works including ''[[Journey to the West]]'' and ''[[Arabian Nights]].'' Some films also have serious themes, especially on environmental topics and the use of technology. Overall, the films have a somewhat darker tone in their stories, unlike the manga and anime. ===Video games=== {{details|List of Doraemon video games}} There are 63 Japanese-only Doraemon video games, ranging from platformer games to RPG games, beginning with the Emerson's [[Arcadia 2001]] system. Doraemon can also be seen in [[Namco]]'s popular ''[[Taiko no Tatsujin]]'' rhythm game series like ''Taiko no Tatsujin'' (11 – [[Taiko no Tatsujin 14|14]] only), ''[[Metcha! Taiko no Tatsujin DS: Nanatsu no Shima no Daibouken]]'', ''[[Taiko no Tatsujin Wii]]'', ''[[Taiko no Tatsujin Plus]]'', and ''[[Taiko no Tatsujin DS: Dororon! Yokai Daikessen!!]]''. The Japanese version of Microsoft's ''3D Movie Maker'' contained a Doraemon-themed expansion pack. The first Doraemon game to receive a Western release was ''[[Doraemon Story of Seasons]]'' (2019). ===Musical=== {{nihongo|''Doraemon the Musical: Nobita and the Animal Planet''|舞台版ドラえもん のび太とアニマル惑星プラネット。|Butaiban Doraemon: Nobita to Animaru Puranetto}} was a 2008 [[musical theatre|musical]] based on the 1990 [[anime]] film [[Doraemon: Nobita and the Animal Planet|of the same name]].[http://dora-world.com/information/event_animal.html Event information] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100326071005/http://www.dora-world.com/information/event_animal.html |date=2010-03-26 }}, [http://dora-world.com/news2112doga/index080808.html News about the musical] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090116214918/http://dora-world.com/news2112doga/index080808.html |date=2009-01-16 }} It debuted at [[Tokyo Metropolitan Art Space]] on September 4, 2008 running through September 14.{{cite web | url=http://www.geigeki.jp/english/event_200809_list.html#02 | title=Events Calendar | publisher=Tokyo Metropolitan Art Space | accessdate=August 13, 2008}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=H3llBot}} [[Wasabi Mizuta]] voiced Doraemon. ==Merchandise== The ''Doraemon '' franchise has had numerous licensed merchandise. In 1999, ''Doraemon'' licensed merchandise sold {{JPY|83.01 billion}} in Japan, where it was the fifth [[List of highest-grossing media franchises|highest-grossing franchise]] annually.{{cite news |title=在日本，地位最高的动漫是哆啦a梦么？ |url=http://www.taojinjubao.com/zhihu/267465.html |website=Taojinjubao |publisher=Character Databank (CharaBiz) |date=2018-01-06 |access-date=2018-09-15 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180909185415/http://www.taojinjubao.com/zhihu/267465.html |archive-date=2018-09-09 |url-status=live }} ''Doraemon'' licensed merchandise in Japan later sold {{JPY|50 billion}} in 2000,{{cite book |title=Market Share in Japan |date=2005 |publisher=Yano Research Institute |page=18 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ppOyAAAAIAAJ |quote=7 {{!}} Doraemon {{!}} 500 [...] 8 {{!}} Doraemon {{!}} 300 |access-date=2018-09-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181120025656/https://books.google.com/books?id=ppOyAAAAIAAJ |archive-date=2018-11-20 |url-status=live }} {{JPY|36.84 billion}} in 2001, {{JPY|30 billion}} in 2003, {{JPY|{{#expr:28.24+24.96+21.78+17.53+13.55}} billion}} during 2004{{ndash}}2008, and {{JPY|{{#expr:16.98+15.9+19.02}} billion}} during 2010{{ndash}}2012, adding up to at least {{JPY|357.81 billion}} ({{US$|{{To USD|357810|JPN|year=2012}} million|long=no}}) licensed merchandise sales in Japan by 2012. Global retail sales of ''Doraemon'' licensed merchandise later generated {{US$|557 million|long=no}} in 2015,{{cite news |title=Top 20 Preschool Properties in the $12.8 Billion Industry |url=https://www.thelicensingletter.com/top-20-preschool-properties-in-the-12-8-billion-industry/ |work=The Licensing Letter |date=July 17, 2017 |access-date=2018-09-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180623113054/https://www.thelicensingletter.com/top-20-preschool-properties-in-the-12-8-billion-industry/ |archive-date=2018-06-23 |url-status=live }} and {{US$|551 million|long=no}} in 2016. {{as of|2016}}, ''Doraemon'' has generated at least {{US$|5.592 billion|long=no}} in licensed merchandise sales. ==Reception== Until 2015, more than 100{{nbsp}}million [[tankobon]] copies of the manga have been sold, and the anime series is available in over 30 countries.{{cite web|url=http://license-new.shopro.co.jp/products/detail/53|title=ドラえもん（TVアニメ）|publisher=Shogakukan Production|language=Japanese|accessdate=2013-11-28|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203002225/http://license-new.shopro.co.jp/products/detail/53|archive-date=2013-12-03|url-status=live}}{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/03/japanese-robot-cat-doraemon-eases-diplomatic-tensions-with-china |title=Japanese robot cat Doraemon helps ease diplomatic tensions with China |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |last=McCurray |first=Justin |date=June 3, 2015 |accessdate=July 18, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160722031540/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/03/japanese-robot-cat-doraemon-eases-diplomatic-tensions-with-china |archive-date=2016-07-22 |url-status=live }} The [[List of Doraemon films|''Doraemon'' film series]] sold more than 103{{nbsp}}million tickets at the [[Cinema of Japan|Japanese box office]] by 2015, surpassing ''[[Godzilla (franchise)|Godzilla]]'' as the [[List of highest-grossing films in Japan|highest-grossing film franchise in Japan]],{{cite news |title=Japan Box Office: 'Doraemon' Anime Still All-Conquering |url=https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/japan-box-office-doraemon-anime-786473 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=April 6, 2015 |access-date=2018-09-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180616053756/https://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/japan-box-office-doraemon-anime-786473 |archive-date=2018-06-16 |url-status=live }} and the films grossed over {{US$|1.6 billion|long=no}} at the worldwide box office, making ''Doraemon'' the [[List of highest-grossing anime films|highest-grossing anime film franchise]].{{efn|name=Anime|See ''{{Section link|List of Doraemon films|Box office performance}}''}} Doraemon was awarded the first [[Shogakukan Manga Award]] for children's manga in 1982. In 1997, it was awarded the first [[Osamu Tezuka Culture Award]].{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/shimbun/award/tezuka/97a.html|language=Japanese|script-title=ja:第1回 マンガ大賞 藤子・Ｆ・不二雄 　『ドラえもん』（小学館）|work=[[Asahi Shimbun]]|accessdate=July 18, 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090503102232/http://www.asahi.com/shimbun/award/tezuka/97a.html|archive-date=2009-05-03|url-status=live}} In 2008, the [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Japan)|Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] appointed Doraemon as the first anime cultural ambassador.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/mar/20/japan|title=Japan enlists cartoon cat as ambassador|last=McCurry|first=Justin|date=20 March 2008|website=[[The Guardian]]|access-date=17 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080323203109/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2008/mar/20/japan|archive-date=2008-03-23|url-status=live}}[http://www.afpbb.com/article/life-culture/life/2364557/2736468 ドラえもん、初の「アニメ文化大使」に任命] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090104072958/http://www.afpbb.com/article/life-culture/life/2364557/2736468 |date=2009-01-04 }}". (March 15, 2008) ''AFPBB News''. Retrieved February 11, 2010.{{in lang|ja}}Shingo, Takaoka . "[http://www.guardian.to/otaku.html Secret power of Otaku culture Spirits] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100426001943/http://www.guardian.to/otaku.html |date=2010-04-26 }}". ''The WASEDA Guardian''. Retrieved February 11, 2010. On 22 April 2002, on the special issue of ''Asian Hero'' in ''Time'' magazine, Doraemon was selected as one of the 22 Asian Heroes. Being the only anime character selected, Doraemon was described as "The Cuddliest Hero in Asia".{{cite news |last=Iyer |first=Pico |url=http://www.time.com/time/asia/features/heroes/doraemon.html |title=The Cuddliest Hero in Asia |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time Asia]] |accessdate=February 17, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100308004845/http://www.time.com/time/asia/features/heroes/doraemon.html |archivedate=March 8, 2010 |date=April 29, 2002 |url-status=live }} In 2005, the Taiwan Society of New York selected ''Doraemon'' as a culturally significant work of Japanese [[otaku]] pop-culture in its exhibit ''Little Boy: The Arts of Japan's Exploding Subculture'', curated by renowned artist [[Takashi Murakami]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.japansociety.org/little_boy_the_arts_of_japans_exploding_subculture|title=Little Boy: The Arts of Japan's Exploding Subculture|website=Japan Society|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180117011852/https://www.japansociety.org/little_boy_the_arts_of_japans_exploding_subculture|archive-date=2018-01-17|url-status=live}} [[Jason Thompson (writer)|Jason Thompson]] praised the "silly situations" and "old fashioned, simple artwork", with Doraemon's expression and comments adding to the "surrounding elementary-school mischief". On September 3, 2012, Doraemon was granted official residence in the city of Kawasaki, one hundred years before he was born.{{cite web|title=Doraemon becomes official resident of Kawasaki a century before his birth|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120904f1.html|work=Japan Times|accessdate=3 September 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108204752/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120904f1.html|archive-date=2012-11-08|url-status=live}} With the 2013 film, ''[[Doraemon: Nobita no Himitsu Dōgu Museum]]'', Doraemon has surpassed [[Godzilla]] in terms of overall ticket sales for a film franchise as Toho's most lucrative movie property. The 33-year series (1980–2013) has sold a combined 100 million tickets vs. the 50-year Godzilla series (1954–2004), which sold a combined 99 million tickets.{{cite news|last=Sekiguchi|first=Toko|title=Godzilla Loses Top Spot to Kittybot Doraemon|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2013/03/26/godzilla-loses-top-spot-to-kittybot-doraemon/|accessdate=March 26, 2013|work=The Wall Street Journal|date=March 26, 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130330002155/http://blogs.wsj.com/japanrealtime/2013/03/26/godzilla-loses-top-spot-to-kittybot-doraemon/|archive-date=2013-03-30|url-status=live}} It also became the largest franchise by numbers of admissions in Japan.{{cite web|url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/japan-box-office-doraemon-anime-786473|title= Japan Box Office: 'Doraemon' Anime Still All-Conquering|author= Gavin J. Blair|date= April 6, 2015|accessdate= May 28, 2015|work= The Hollywood Reporter|archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20150528220457/http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/japan-box-office-doraemon-anime-786473|archive-date= 2015-05-28|url-status= live}} The [[Doraemon in India|''Doraemon'' anime series is India's]] highest-rated children's television show {{as of|2017|lc=y}}, with a total of 478.5{{nbsp}}million viewers across [[Hungama TV]] and [[Disney Channel India]].{{cite news |title="Reason Behind The Cuteness Of Doraemon, Chhota Bheem And Powerpuff Girls!" Voice In Every Family {{!}} Sonal Kaushal - Student Stories |url=https://m.dailyhunt.in/news/india/english/student+stories-epaper-stustr/reason+behind+the+cuteness+of+doraemon+chhota+bheem+and+powerpuff+girls+voice+in+every+family+sonal+kaushal-newsid-69049749 |work=[[Dailyhunt]] |date=June 16, 2017 |access-date=2018-09-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180907032357/https://m.dailyhunt.in/news/india/english/student+stories-epaper-stustr/reason+behind+the+cuteness+of+doraemon+chhota+bheem+and+powerpuff+girls+voice+in+every+family+sonal+kaushal-newsid-69049749 |archive-date=2018-09-07 |url-status=live }} ''Doraemon'' is similarly popular in neighbouring [[Pakistan]], where the [[Hindi]]-dubbed version is aired (Hindi and [[Urdu]] are [[mutually intelligible]]). Its popularity has led to controversy in both countries. In 2016, politicians and conservative activists in both India and Pakistan campaigned to ban the show from television because they claimed it "corrupts children."{{cite news |last1=McCurry |first1=Justin |title=Japanese robot cat Doraemon raises hackles in India and Pakistan |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/07/doraemon-japanese-robot-cat-raises-hackles-in-india-and-pakistan |accessdate=16 April 2019 |work=[[The Guardian]] |date=7 October 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190415093722/https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/oct/07/doraemon-japanese-robot-cat-raises-hackles-in-india-and-pakistan |archive-date=15 April 2019 |url-status=live |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news |last1=Kuronuma |first1=Yuji |title=Fictional cat Doraemon gets a bad rap in India and Pakistan |url=https://asia.nikkei.com/NAR/Articles/Fictional-cat-Doraemon-gets-a-bad-rap-in-India-and-Pakistan |accessdate=16 April 2019 |work=[[Nikkei Asian Review]] |date=3 November 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190417130302/https://asia.nikkei.com/NAR/Articles/Fictional-cat-Doraemon-gets-a-bad-rap-in-India-and-Pakistan |archive-date=17 April 2019 |url-status=live |df=dmy-all }} In India, legal notices were served against several companies in [[India]], targeting ''Doraemon'' and ''[[Crayon Shin-chan]]'', as having an adverse effect on children.The [[Government of Bangladesh]] banned the Indian feeds of Disney Channel and [[Disney XD (India)|Disney XD]] in February 2013 as the show ''[[Doraemon]]'' was being broadcast continuously throughout the day in Hindi In Pakistan, ''Doraemon'' was targeted by the political party [[Pakistan Tehreek-e-Insaf]] as having a negative impact on children, because of Nobita's constant reliance on Doraemon's gadgets to solve problems, and they attempted to ban 24 hour [[cartoon]] channels in general, because of their supposed ruining of children's minds. They also attempted to ban the Hindi dub of the series, as Pakistan's official language is Urdu. {{cite news |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-08-04/resolution-to-ban-doraemon-anime-series-submitted-in-pakistan/.105034 |title=Resolution to Ban Doraemon Anime Series Submitted in Pakistan |work=[[Anime News Network]] |date=August 4, 2016 |accessdate=August 10, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160805181931/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2016-08-04/resolution-to-ban-doraemon-anime-series-submitted-in-pakistan/.105034 |archive-date=2016-08-05 |url-status=live }} ==Legacy== [[File:Kawasakicitybus-w-1878.jpg|Shuttle bus featuring Doraemon to Fujiko F. Fujio Museum in [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa|Kawasaki]]|thumb]] A Fujiko F. Fujio museum opened in [[Kawasaki, Kanagawa|Kawasaki]] on September 3, 2011, featuring Doraemon as the star of the museum.{{cite news | url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/anime-star-doraemon-to-have-own-museum-2345688.html | work=The Independent | date=29 August 2011 | location=London | title=Anime star Doraemon to have own museum | access-date=2017-08-22 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150925014515/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/tv/anime-star-doraemon-to-have-own-museum-2345688.html | archive-date=2015-09-25 | url-status=live }}{{Cite web|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2011/09/04/national/doraemon-museum-opens-its-doors/|title=Doraemon museum opens its doors|date=4 September 2011|website=[[The Japan Times]]|access-date=17 April 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181120025657/https://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2011/09/04/national/doraemon-museum-opens-its-doors/|archive-date=20 November 2018|url-status=live|df=dmy-all}} As one of the oldest, continuously running icons, Doraemon is a recognizable character in this contemporary generation. Nobita, the show's protagonist, is a break from other characters typically portrayed as special or extraordinary, and this portrayal has been seen as reasons of its appeal as well as the contrary, especially in the United States.{{cite news|author=TETSUO IWAMOTO, Asahi Staff Writer |url=http://ajw.asahi.com/article/cool_japan/culture/AJ201209030098 |title=Happy birthday! Doraemon will be born 100 years from today |work=[[Asahi Shimbun]] |date=2012-09-03 |accessdate=2014-01-15 |url-status=dead |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140116124215/https://ajw.asahi.com/article/cool_japan/culture/AJ201209030098 |archivedate=2014-01-16 }} Mexican filmmaker [[Guillermo del Toro]] considers ''Doraemon'' to be "the greatest kids series ever created".{{cite tweet|number=820437584090370048|user=RealGDT|title=Love that u guys love Trollhunters. May I suggest that you seek the greatest kids series ever created... Doraemon by master Fujiko F. Fujio.|author=[[Guillermo del Toro]]|date=14 January 2017|accessdate=15 January 2017}} [[ESP Guitars]] have made several Doraemon guitars aimed at children.{{cite web |url=http://espguitars.co.jp/doraemon/index.html |title=ESP X Doraemon |archiveurl=https://archive.today/20130903175610/http://espguitars.co.jp/doraemon/index.html |archivedate=September 3, 2013 |publisher=[[ESP Guitars]]}}{{cite web |url=http://www.espguitars.co.jp/doraemon/index.html |title=ESP X Doraemon |accessdate=December 26, 2014 |publisher=[[ESP Guitars]] |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150220052620/http://www.espguitars.co.jp/doraemon/index.html |archive-date=2015-02-20 |url-status=live }} In late 2011, Shogakukan and [[Toyota]] joined forces to create a series of live-action commercials as part of Toyota's ReBorn ad campaign. The commercials depict the characters nearly 20 years older. Hollywood actor [[Jean Reno]] plays Doraemon.{{cite web|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-07-14/jean-reno-goes-to-olympics-as-doraemon-in-new-live-action-ad|title=Jean Reno Goes to Olympics as Doraemon in New Live-Action Ad – News|date=2013-01-27|work=Anime News Network|accessdate=2013-01-31|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121108100519/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/news/2012-07-14/jean-reno-goes-to-olympics-as-doraemon-in-new-live-action-ad|archive-date=2012-11-08|url-status=live}} Doraemon has become a prevalent part of popular [[Culture of Japan|culture in Japan]]. Newspapers also regularly make references to Doraemon and his pocket as something with the ability to satisfy all wishes. The series is frequently referenced in other series such as ''[[Gin Tama]]'' and ''[[Great Teacher Onizuka]]''.{{cite news |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/gintama/episode-272/.88389 |title=Gintama Episode 272 |work=[[Anime News Network]] |date=May 21, 2015 |accessdate=April 16, 2016 |last=McNulty |first=Amy |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160402043358/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/gintama/episode-272/.88389 |archive-date=2016-04-02 |url-status=live }}{{cite news|url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/gto/14-days-in-shonan/gn-4|title=GTO: 14 Days in Shonan GN 4|last=Santos|first=Carlo|date=September 23, 2012|work=[[Anime News Network]]|accessdate=April 16, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160403042227/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/review/gto/14-days-in-shonan/gn-4|archive-date=2016-04-03|url-status=live}} Doraemon appears in appeals for charity. [[TV Asahi]] launched the ''Doraemon Fund'' charity fund to raise money for natural disasters.{{cite web |title=Doraemon Fund |url=http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/doraemonbokin/|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040111135443/http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/doraemonbokin/ |archivedate=January 11, 2004 |work=[[TV Asahi]]}} Doraemon, Nobita, and the other characters also appear in various educational manga.{{cite book |title=Manga:Sixty years of Japanese Comics |publisher=Laurence King Publishing |isbn=1-85669-391-0 |last=Gravett |first=Paul|date=2004-08-03 }}{{cite web |url=http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2011-06-22/shogakukan-publishes-doraemon-earthquake-survival-guide |title=Shogakukan Publishes Doraemon Earthquake Survival Guide |work=[[Anime News Network]] |date=June 22, 2011 |accessdate=January 5, 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924160023/http://www.animenewsnetwork.com/interest/2011-06-22/shogakukan-publishes-doraemon-earthquake-survival-guide |archive-date=2015-09-24 |url-status=live }} Doraemon appeared in the [[2016 Summer Olympics closing ceremony]] to promote the [[2020 Summer Olympics]] in [[Tokyo]].{{cite news|last1=Palazzo|first1=Chiara|title=Shinzo Abe emerges from a green pipe disguised as Super Mario during Rio Closing Ceremony|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/olympics/2016/08/22/shinzo-abe-emerges-from-a-green-pipe-disguised-as-super-mario-du/|work=The Daily Telegraph|accessdate=August 22, 2016|date=August 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822025340/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/olympics/2016/08/22/shinzo-abe-emerges-from-a-green-pipe-disguised-as-super-mario-du/|archive-date=2016-08-22|url-status=live}}{{cite news|last1=Samuelson|first1=Kate|title=Shinzo Abe Dresses as Super Mario for Rio Closing Ceremony|url=http://time.com/4460923/super-mario-japan-prime-minister-shinzo-abe/|accessdate=August 22, 2016|work=TIME.com|date=August 22, 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160822100538/http://time.com/4460923/super-mario-japan-prime-minister-shinzo-abe/|archive-date=2016-08-22|url-status=live}} ==See also== {{Portal|Anime and manga}} {{Wikipedia books}} *[[List of non-Japanese Doraemon versions]] **[[Doraemon in India|''Doraemon'' in India]] **[[Doraemon: Gadget Cat from the Future|''Doraemon'' in the United States]] **[[Doraemon in Vietnam|''Doraemon'' in Vietnam]] *''[[Dorabase]]'', a spin-off about robot cats who can play in a [[baseball]] team. *''[[Ninja Hattori-kun]]'' *''[[21 Emon]]'', a manga by Fujiko F. Fujio set in the same universe. *''[[Kiteretsu Daihyakka]]'' ==Notes== {{notelist}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} {{wikiquote}} *[http://www.dora-world.com/ ''Doraemon'' Official Website] {{in lang|ja}} *[http://www.dora-movie.com/ ''Doraemon'' Movie Official Website (1980–2009)] {{in lang|ja}} *[http://www.tv-asahi.co.jp/doraemon/ ''Doraemon'' Official TV Asahi Website''] {{in lang|ja}} *[http://www.doraemon.com/ ''Doraemon'' Official US website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20100209060222/http://doraemon.yahoo.co.jp/ ''Doraemon'' features for adults] (Opens January and closes May every year) {{in lang|ja}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060411064800/http://www.proc.org.tohoku.ac.jp/~hoshi/doraemon/doraemon.euc ''Doraemon'' Secret ''Dōgu'' List], a comprehensive list of ''dōgu'' featured in ''Doraemon'' {{in lang|ja}} *[http://www.shogakukan.co.jp/books/series/_id_B30012 ''Doraemon'' English Comics from Shogakukan]; [http://www.shogakukan.co.jp/books/detail/_isbn_4092270216 Complete set] {{in lang|ja}} *{{ann|manga|1335}} {{Portal bar|Japan|Science fiction|Anime and manga|Video games|1960s|1980s|1990s}} {{Doraemon}} {{Fujiko Fujio}} {{Shogakukan Manga Award - Children}} {{Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize}} [[Category:Doraemon]] [[Category:1969 manga]] [[Category:Animated television series about cats]] [[Category:Animated television series about dysfunctional families]] [[Category:Children's manga]] [[Category:Comedy anime and manga]] [[Category:Comics about cats]] [[Category:Comics about time travel]] [[Category:Comics set in the 22nd century]] [[Category:CoroCoro Comic]] [[Category:Fictional artificial intelligences]] [[Category:Fujiko F Fujio]] [[Category:Jetix original programming]] [[Category:Manga adapted into films]] [[Category:Television series about shapeshifting]] [[Category:Science fiction anime and manga]] [[Category:Shogakukan franchises]] [[Category:Shogakukan manga]] [[Category:Shunsuke Kikuchi]] [[Category:TV Asahi shows]] [[Category:Viz Media anime]] [[Category:Winner of Tezuka Osamu Cultural Prize (Grand Prize)]] [[Category:Winners of the Shogakukan Manga Award for children's manga]]
